item.title: US hails victory in UBS tax battle
item.description: The US yesterday blasted a huge hole in Switzerland’s famed hallowed bank secrecy as Bern agreed to reveal the names of 4,450 wealthy rich Americans holding offshore accounts at UBS, the country’s biggest bank

item.title: CBS and Pepsi bring video ads to printed page
item.description: When some Entertainment Weekly readers open their magazines next month, they will discover peopleadvertisements talking to them from a wafer-thin video screen built into the printed page.

item.title: White House hopeful on health reform
item.description: The White House sought to quell suggestions it was preparing to pull the plug on further negotiations with the Republicans over healthcare reform even though the large majoritymost are bitterly opposed to nearly any Democratic-inspired change

item.title: Taliban target Afghan polling stations
item.description: Officials and civilians have received warnings that militants will target voters in addition to military and government institutions.

item.title: Deere quarterly earnings beat expectations
item.description: John Deere, the world’s biggest maker of agricultural equipment, indicated that it did not expect to make a profit in the remainder of its fiscal yearwould struggle to make a profit in its current fiscal quarter, as it warned it faced “persistent global economic pressure”

item.title: Rivals jostle in the electric car charge
item.description: Green Technology, part three: In spite of the deep crisis in the automotive industry, several large carmakers are taking a gamble on electric cars. Governments globally are helping with generous subsidies and tax breaks for zero- and low-emission vehicles

item.title: Developed markets feel China impact
item.description: The sickly Chinese stock market that has been blamed for infecting markets in other parts of the world

item.title: More than 95 dead in Baghdad attacks
item.description: Baghdad suffered a string of attacks that left more than 95 people dead in the latest sign that violence in Iraq has intensified in the wake of a handover from US troops to Iraqi security forces.

item.title: ECB urges further stimulus measures
item.description: Emergency growth-stimulating policies are still needed to support Europe’s fragile economic recovery, Axel Weber, Germany’s Bundesbank president, has warned

item.title: Sony cuts Slim PS3 price to lure players
item.description: Sony’s games consoles have endured a fall from grace. In the previous round of the console wars, Sony’s PlayStation2 stormed the market, selling 138m units to date, compared with about 24m Microsoft XBoxes and 22m Nintendo GameCubes
